review_title: A friendly, teaching focused institution with a genuine commitment to providing continued education for mature students.
pros: - Friendly, approachable staff who make themselves available out of hours, share their enthusiasm for what they teach and accommodate students who are studying while working - something that has become increasingly important as people now have longer more varied careers.
cons:
- A lack of direct contact with staff due to an evening timetable designed for currently employed students. 
- A wide variety of loosely connected/related courses which makes it difficult to specialise in order to gain expertise in a particular area.  
- Few research staff who must devote a significant amount of their time to teaching, thus limiting the opportunities for research which are significantly better in universities with larger and more numerous research groups.

pros: My review has to do with one school. Not the entire college. Students are mainly mature European students. Knowledgeable, hard working and very well educated (most of them have a degree or are mid-career) and appreciate good lecturers very much because they see many who teach "Wikipedia" courses.
cons: Lecturers taught versions of accounting standards which were replaced a decade ago. You mention that, you are out. As simple as that. Of course, the official reason is something else. They will prefer to employ people who have no subject relevant experience than to employ well qualified, good lecturers who have industry experience. Looking at CVs on the site, one can see who those people are. They belong to the core. Power relations are difficult to identify and measure. However, actions, overall show a specific pattern.  You keep quiet, all is fine. You say "this is wrong, we cannot be teaching today what was replaced 10 years ago" you find yourself against the invisible structure. It does not matter how evidently good you are, you are out.

pros:
A great workplace in general - good, motivated staff; a unique ethos in higher education provision; great benefits and work/life balance; people really believe in the place.
People are very conscious of the social mobility ethos and this runs right through from academics to external relations, and extends to the staff in the form of good workplace rights, a consciousness of union presence, and an eagerness across most teams to create a positive, constructive, and enriching environment for progress. With low budgets and high personal responsibility, we are built of scrappy teams of mostly very motivated people who love what they do.
cons: Can (like most universities) be a rather political place to work. Power balance between departments can create some uncomfortable working situations, and there is some endemic stubbornness to change. They are outnumbered by positive staff, however there are pockets of indignant difficult people who seem to prefer sniping at others and go out of their way to make others' jobs difficult or uncomfortable. It's the downside to an empowering workplace conscious of workers' rights- you get some who let this turn into entitlement to rude or passive-aggressive behaviour.

review_title: You can work at better Universities
pros: Pay, flexible working and holiday allowance a massive plus.
cons:
Birkbeck seem to talk about having very good ideas about how to take the College forward, but aren't able to put those ideas into practice because there is so much internal politics and they refuse to spend any money.
There are a lot of employees that have been at Birkbeck a very long time, and its quite clear they are staying there until they retire. Good for them? However means that there's lots of internal politics, and most new ideas to push the College forward never happen because there's so many people stuck in their ways.
Working at Birkbeck knocked my confidence, mainly because you rarely have one to one's and never know if you are doing a good or a bad job?
Awful working environment with no heating/air con and ancient facilities.
There's many other Universities you could work where I'm sure you would have a better experience.

review_title: Inspiring institution, great place to work
job_title: Professor of Law in London, England
pros:
The tradition of Birkbeck, starting with George Birkbeck's creation in the early 19th century of a Mechanic's Institution, where working Londoners can achieve a higher education. 
With 19,000 students now and a full range of academic disciplines, Birkbeck is a top notch research and teaching university.
Birkbeck attracts wonderfully committed students, who choose to give up many evenings while working and bringing up families - the best students I have taught, and this is my fourth teaching post.
Inspiring colleagues, and a genuinely collegiate atmosphere.
The best possible location, in Bloomsbury surrounded by libraries, institutes and several University of London colleges.
cons: We have run out of space - most law teaching takes place in Friend's House in Euston Road.

pros: No need to set the alarm for the early hours of the morning. An unusually interesting student body, at least among the more advanced students.
cons: The students look down on you unless you have grey hair. Management turn a blind eye to people not doing their jobs and the promotion system is fundamentally broken. The array of subjects offered show it to be more of a mickey-mouse institution rather than anywhere serious, indeed it's almost an embarrassment to admit to working there when meeting people at conferences, for example. Seems to be in a constant state of financial crisis, blaming government all the time.

pros: The friendliest office I've ever worked in, and relatively well paid. The work is interesting and colleagues are clever. They encourage you to take advantage of Birkbeck's evening study as well, and offer up to 95% off tuition fees if you want to take a course as a staff member.  Great location, flexible hours and generous annual leave.
cons: High turnover in administrative staff. Talking to colleagues who've left, this often seems to be related to career progression. Roles are more 'fixed' than in the private sector so often if you know your boss has no plans to leave, you don't have a realistic chance of promotion.

review_title: Friendly work atmosphere but little room for progression
pros: The people here are really friendly (bar a few of course) and there are different training courses available for staff to attend free of charge
cons: The progression here is pretty slow. You often have to take a sideways step to get to what you really want to do. On the plus side mangers are very encouraging of progression as and when it does become available

pros: nothing, nada, nichts, ingenting, rien, tipota
cons:
Fom an academic's point of view, reflecting on 2 years' experience at the School of Management, if you are a careerist, a ruffian, thriving in the dark arts, generally incompetent, but perhaps have strong backing from your buddies and network, you will thrive here!! This is the place where if you cannot get a job elsewhere due to some serious deficiency in your character and morals, you will find here a Heaven of institutionalised bullying, harassment, and abuse - aided and abetted by HR, and UCU - in a dog-eat-dog culture. Promotion depends primarily on whom you have support from, who is your buddy, and how efficient you may have been on getting rid off anyone else who may had talent and something new to say. Also, if you cannot teach (just read out notes) and cannot do any original research either (but you're so good in networking that your "co-authored" nonsense will get published) you'll definitely make it to Senior Lecturer and Reader.
“Internal politics” (a euphemism for bullying at all levels) are so distastefully strong that even if you are a respected and well-know scholar with decades of contribution to society, you will be kicked unceremoniously out!
If you are a decent human being, with values, and principles do not even be tempted to enter! 
Financially, it survives because lets anyone who wants to study enter and then without any extra resources (Academic Services haven been decimated) are expected to graduate. Some students will thrive. A lot are just kicking time and expect to graduate. Some "clever" students will complaint about everything and the general incompetent Dean will do their outmost not to dissatisfy the fee-paying (but incapable of academic study) student-customer. If you're a junior academic or an Associate you'll be abused and bullied mercilessly till you either leave (with your reputation ruined) or join in and become an abuser, too.

job_title: Assistant School Manager in London, England
pros: Collegiate, management style allows autonomy, positive colleagues with a good sense of humor, flexible working conditions accommodates changes in lifestyle. Good benefits - salary exchanges available. Great employer - I work with people from all walks of life. Can work from home.
cons: Don't feel particularly pushed to perform, although I know I am valued for the work I do.

job_title: Teaching and Research in London, England
pros: I loved the fact that most students were mature and they knew what they wanted. As a teacher you could create a relaxed atmosphere where everybody could participate and was included.
cons: the only negative aspect about BBK was that you get hoe at 10.00, although that could also be a plus.

pros: A great work environment filled with people that are very focused and enjoy working together on projects! You will definitely grow as a scholar and researcher here.
cons: I think that the cons that I have noticed are very subjective and I do not want to bias anyone's experience of this place with my own views.

pros: Good place for work, flexible hours and different opportunities. If you are student you can collaborate with them but you need to pass a selection with other candidates.
cons: Need to be open mind and fluent in English also if is not a must but is needed because is the basic language used by all international students.

pros: Offer discounted part time study alongside work
cons: No raining programme in place. Very little enthusiasm from staff, sombre place to work.
